query: Map the timeline of all work stoppages or delays.
hypothesis: The core dispute involves significant work stoppages or delays, primarily attributed to Gulfstream's deficient maintenance and planning processes, stemming from issues like its failure to adequately address corrosion during the 2020 144-Month Inspection. These prior deficiencies led to a recurrence of extensive corrosion, necessitating significant additional work, 'hundreds of additional labor hours,' and 'further engineering dispositions' during the subsequent 192-Month Inspection, contributing to substantial cost overruns, extended downtime, and significant damages to the Aircraft owner. Further investigation is needed to confirm the role of the St. Louis facility and to quantify specific delays and costs.
final_output:
**MEMORANDUM**

**TO:** Senior Partner
**FROM:** [Your Name]
**DATE:** October 26, 2023
**RE:** Timeline and Causation of Work Stoppages and Delays; CITIOM v. Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation; G550 Aircraft, SN 5174, OE-LIM

---

### Executive Summary

The 192-Month Inspection of CITIOM’s G550 aircraft, initially estimated to take 35-45 working days, resulted in a total downtime of approximately 10 months. The timeline is defined by a massive underestimation of labor, multiple missed completion deadlines, and a formal work stoppage on June 17, 2024, due to a payment dispute, all stemming from the discovery of extensive corrosion that added over 20,000 manhours to the original 2,800-hour estimate.

### Factual Background

The dispute centers on the 192-Month Inspection of CITIOM’s Gulfstream G550 aircraft (the "Aircraft") at Gulfstream's St. Louis facility. The project was initiated on January 28, 2024, with the Aircraft going out of service the following day. Gulfstream’s proposal estimated the work would require 2,800 manhours and a maximum ground time of 45 working days, projecting a return to service (RTS) date of March 29, 2024. [CITIOM Statement of Claim.pdf, p. 3]

This initial timeline was quickly rendered obsolete. Due to a significant increase in the work scope, an end-of-April completion was deemed impossible. The RTS date was subsequently postponed multiple times, with projected dates including April 1 and June 21, 2024, consistently being missed. [NO exhibits - CITIOM EXPERT REPORT - D. Farnham Expert Report - Mar 21 2025 copy.pdf, p. 15 [UNVERIFIED]; 1-66.pdf, p. 5 [UNVERIFIED]].

The project experienced a formal work stoppage on June 17, 2024, when Gulfstream ceased work due to an unpaid interim invoice. This action was preceded by warnings from Gulfstream that failure to adhere to the progress payment schedule would result in such a stoppage. [Evidence Gathered; Combined_20250505172300.pdf, p. 182 [UNVERIFIED]].

Following the discovery of extensive discrepancies, primarily related to corrosion, the work scope expanded dramatically. An additional 20,000 manhours were added to the project, and the estimated completion was pushed to mid-November 2024. [Evidence Gathered; 207-329.pdf, p. 2 [UNVERIFIED]]. CITIOM alleges the Aircraft remained out of service from January 29, 2024, through November 29, 2024, resulting in damages calculated at approximately €2.4 million. [Evidence Gathered; CITIOM v. Gulfstream-FAZ Report.pdf, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]].

### Analysis

#### Key Findings

*   **Massive Timeline Discrepancy:** The project's duration extended from an estimated 45 working days to an actual downtime of 10 months. [CITIOM Statement of Claim.pdf, p. 3; Evidence Gathered]
*   **Formal Work Stoppage:** A distinct work stoppage occurred on June 17, 2024, contractually justified by Gulfstream as resulting from an unpaid invoice. [Evidence Gathered]
*   **Drastic Scope Expansion:** The primary driver of the delay was an unforeseen work scope increase of over 700%, from an estimated 2,800 manhours to more than 22,800 total manhours, attributed to extensive corrosion. [CITIOM Statement of Claim.pdf, p. 3; 207-329.pdf, p. 2 [UNVERIFIED]]
*   **Alleged Negligence by Gulfstream:** CITIOM's experts allege the scope expansion and resulting delays were caused by Gulfstream's failure to identify and address corrosion issues during prior maintenance events in 2020 and 2023, coupled with deficient planning and resource allocation at its St. Louis facility. [Working Hypothesis; NO exhibits - CITIOM EXPERT REPORT - D. Farnham Expert Report - Mar 21 2025 copy.pdf, p. 5 [UNVERIFIED]]

#### Supporting Evidence

The strongest evidence establishing the project's baseline is found in CITIOM's Statement of Claim, which states Gulfstream "originally estimated 2,800 manhours were required to perform the 192-month inspection" with a "maximum ground time of 45 working days" and a planned RTS of March 29th. [CITIOM Statement of Claim.pdf, p. 3]. This is the only verified citation directly supporting the initial timeline.

The total alleged downtime is established by CITIOM's claim that the Aircraft was out of service from January 29, 2024, through November 29, 2024. [Evidence Gathered]. The specific work stoppage is dated to June 17, 2024, due to an "unpaid interim invoice." [Evidence Gathered].

Expert reports, though unverified, provide the basis for CITIOM's theory of causation. The D. Farnham report points to a "lack of proactive planning" and "Failure to identify and address corrosion issues during prior maintenance" as root causes of the "escalating delays and cost overruns." [NO exhibits - CITIOM EXPERT REPORT - D. Farnham Expert Report - Mar 21 2025 copy.pdf, p. 7, 5, 15 [UNVERIFIED]].

#### Contradictions or Concerns

The central point of contention is the cause of the delay. CITIOM frames it as a consequence of Gulfstream's mismanagement and prior negligence. Gulfstream’s defense appears to be that the delays were caused by the discovery of "discrepancies in the Aircraft... that were unpredictable." [In re CITCOM v Gulfstream...pdf, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]].

Furthermore, while CITIOM attributes the delay entirely to Gulfstream, the work stoppage on June 17, 2024, was triggered by CITIOM's non-payment. Gulfstream had a contractual right to stop work under these circumstances, which complicates attributing the entirety of the downtime solely to Gulfstream's performance. [Combined_20250505172300.pdf, p. 182 [UNVERIFIED]].

#### Evidence Strength Assessment

**Moderate.** The evidence provides a clear narrative and timeline of events. The presence of multiple expert reports (Farnham, FAZ Forensics) suggests a well-documented case from the claimant's side. However, the strength is limited because only one of the 94 citations provided is marked as verified. The conclusions heavily rely on quotes from unverified legal briefs and expert reports, which must be independently substantiated.

### Entities & Relationships

*   **CITIOM (Channel IT Isle of Man Ltd.):** Claimant; owner and operator of the Gulfstream G550 Aircraft, OE-LIM.
*   **Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation:** Respondent; Maintenance, Repair, and Overhaul (MRO) provider that conducted the 192-Month Inspection at its St. Louis facility.
*   **D. Farnham:** CITIOM's technical expert, retained to evaluate Gulfstream's performance.
*   **FAZ Forensics:** CITIOM's financial expert, retained to calculate economic damages.

### Gaps & Limitations

*   **Document Verification:** The primary limitation is the unverified status of nearly all cited documents. The contents of these documents are alleged and cannot be definitively relied upon until the source files are obtained and reviewed.
*   **Gulfstream's Documentation:** There is a lack of primary evidence from Gulfstream's perspective, such as internal project management logs, resource allocation schedules for the St. Louis facility, or correspondence explaining the discovery of discrepancies.
*   **Causation Granularity:** The evidence does not provide a detailed breakdown linking specific technical findings (e.g., the "Air Starter Duct Issue") to precise periods of delay. A comprehensive critical path analysis appears to be missing.
*   **Work Stoppage Details:** While the fact and date of the payment-related work stoppage are noted, the surrounding context, including the amount of the disputed invoice and correspondence between the parties, is not available.

### Recommendations

1.  **Immediate Actions:**
    *   Prioritize obtaining and verifying all key documents cited, particularly the expert reports by D. Farnham and FAZ Forensics, Gulfstream's Proposal #Q-11876, and all correspondence related to project delays and the June 17, 2024 work stoppage.
    *   Thoroughly analyze Gulfstream's contractual terms, focusing on clauses related to limitation of liability and exclusion of consequential damages. [In re CITCOM v Gulfstream...pdf, p. 3 [UNVERIFIED]].

2.  **Additional Investigation Needed:**
    *   Serve targeted Requests for Production on Gulfstream for all project management files, daily progress reports, and internal communications related to the Aircraft inspection.
    *   Depose key Gulfstream personnel, including the project manager and lead technicians at the St. Louis facility, to investigate planning, resource allocation, and the timeline for discovering and reporting discrepancies.
    *   Engage a scheduling expert to perform a critical path analysis to determine the precise causes of delay and apportion responsibility between Gulfstream's performance and the client-initiated work stoppage.

3.  **Risk Mitigation Steps:**
    *   Evaluate the strength of a potential gross negligence claim, as this may be required to overcome contractual limitations on consequential damages.
    *   Quantify the delay specifically attributable to the June 17, 2024 work stoppage to isolate it from delays allegedly caused by Gulfstream's performance issues. This will be critical in damages calculations and settlement negotiations.

Georgia law implies a 'reasonable time' for performance when a contract is silent on the matter.
Contractual limitations on damages are generally valid under Georgia law, unless they purport to relieve liability for gross negligence or willful/wanton conduct.

The initial estimated maximum ground time was 45 working days, with a scheduled RTS of March 29th.
On June 17, 2024, work ceased due to an unpaid interim invoice, with outstanding billing concerns.
The unavailability of a replacement for the WTBF Frame PN 1159B51246-39 was cited as making RTS prediction impossible, with an estimated date set for January 6th, 2025.
The RTS forecast was extended to December 16th, 2024, citing unclear reasons related to the left hand floor beam angle cap.
Questions regarding the LBL 30.50 floor beam angle cap replacement have remained unanswered.
Previously uncommunicated options for repair are only being investigated after client interventions.
The holiday schedule of the STM (Service Team Manager) and any appointed deputies were not communicated.
Multiple parts sent out for repair have not yielded timely updates, requiring direct inquiry from the client.
Alternative methods to shorten ground time only surfaced after persistent client efforts.
Leonard A. Beauchemin was retained by counsel for Gulfstream to serve as an expert in this arbitration.
Beauchemin was asked to review the expert report prepared by Danny Farnham and documents relating to the 192-month inspection of the G550 S/N 5174 aircraft.
Beauchemin's expertise includes 42 years of business jet aircraft maintenance and management experience, with positions ranging from technician to Vice President of maintenance.
Beauchemin worked for nine years with Bombardier MRO, overseeing heavy inspection, structural repair, and modifications on similar class airframes.
Beauchemin managed and procured proposals for hundreds of business jet aircraft inspections and modifications across numerous MRO facilities, including Gulfstream.

Beauchemin's opinions include that the Farnham report misconstrues roles of owner/operator vs. OEM/MRO, misstates industry standards for MRO information, and that the Gulfstream proposal was not 'misleading'.
Beauchemin claims the Farnham report is incorrect in stating prior corrosion findings should have predicted extensive corrosion at the 192-month inspection.
Beauchemin states the Farnham report offers no evidence for claims that Gulfstream failed to properly inspect and correct corrosion findings during the 144-month inspection.
Beauchemin asserts it's common for MROs to move technicians between aircraft during extended maintenance and to use other facilities/vendors.
Beauchemin founded and manages AeroTechna Solutions, LLC, an aviation advisory, technical management, and training company.
Beauchemin is an FAA certified Airframe and Powerplant (A&P) technician with Inspection Authorization and holds a private pilot certificate.
Beauchemin served as Chairperson of the Maintenance Committee of the National Business Aviation Association (NBAA).
Beauchemin served as Chairperson of the Bombardier Global Express (GX) Maintenance Program Industry Steering Committee (ISC), leading MSG-3 activities.
Beauchemin also served on the Gulfstream committee responsible for developing the maintenance program for the GV (G550) aircraft.
Beauchemin served as Vice Chair on the Standards Board for International Standards for Business Aircraft Operations (IS-BAO).

Beauchemin managed oversight and management of a fluctuating fleet of 30-40 aircraft, including various Gulfstream models (GIIB, GIII, GIV, GV), during his tenure as V.P. Technical Service for Flight Works.
Beauchemin was a member of an FAA Advisory Rule Making Committee responsible for rewriting standards for aircraft reliability programs (AC 120-17A).

CITIOM objects to Gulfstream's general instruction to produce documents from November 2018 through the date documents are collected, and will only produce responsive documents from March 2020 through the date documents are collected.
CITIOM objects to Request No. 1 (location of Aircraft) as overbroad and will produce flight logs from July 2020 to present.
CITIOM advises that the Aircraft was not put into storage during the period 2018 to present in response to Request No. 2 (storage and hangering).

CITIOM will produce documents sufficient to show the number and model of the Bombardier CL-600-2B16 Challenger 605, serial number 5745, owned by Mr. Haidar, in response to Request No. 3 (other aircraft owned by CITIOM or Bassim Haidar).

CITIOM agrees to produce Mr. Farnham’s curriculum vitae and documents sufficient to show the number and model of Gulfstream Aircraft that Avcon has managed since July 2020, in response to Request No. 4 (Avcon/Farnham experience with Gulfstream aircraft).

CITIOM objects to Request No. 6 (corrosion repairs by entities other than Gulfstream) on the grounds that Gulfstream performed all regular maintenance, and agrees to produce responsive documents not in Gulfstream's possession.

CITIOM agrees to produce non-privileged documents responsive to Request No. 7 (communications regarding the 192-month inspection quoting, scheduling, and induction) and objections are made to documents in Gulfstream's possession, custody, or control.

CITIOM agrees to produce documents responsive to Request No. 8 (communications regarding the 192-month inspection, including downtime and cost) and objections are made to documents in Gulfstream's possession, custody, or control.
The 192-month inspection is mentioned in Requests 7 and 8, indicating it is a significant event in the dispute.

The original work order quote estimated 2800 manhours was needed to perform the required inspections and services associated with the 192-month inspection. The number and type of discrepancies that were discovered during the inspection process, beyond the original work scope and requiring rectificat

Based upon our current projection, the estimated completion date will likely be in mid-November. This is subject to change depending on the repair dispositions provided by engineering once all of the corrosion is evaluated.
Please know that in order to expedite this work, we are currently providing overtime labor at no charge.

This Expert Report (“Report”) concludes that Channel IT Isle of Man Ltd. (“CITIOM” or the “Claimant”) has suffered economic damages of approximately €2.4 million1 as a direct result of Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation’s (“Gulfstream” or the “Respondent”) breaches and failures related to the 192-Mont

These consequential damages are comprised of: Lost Financial Contribution: €1,613,175, representing the net profit the Aircraft would have generated from charter operations during 2024 “but for” Gulfstream’s actions. Additional Consequential Costs: €814,067, representing out-of-pocket travel expense
This Report details the methodology and data underlying this damage calculation.

I am reaching out to formally express our concerns and dissatisfaction regarding the efficiency and level of service exhibited during the 192 MOS inspection project initiated on January 28, 2024, for the Gulfstream G550, SN 5174, OE-LIM.
We have observed significant delays, which we attribute to what appears to be inadequate organization and effectiveness on the part of your team.
Since April 2024, the estimated return to service (RTS) date has been continually postponed without clear and timely explanations.
Last Friday during our conference call I questioned the ongoing issue of manpower, your only response was, "I will look into it."

Over the last 6 months we have been told that everything possible was being done to hire, bring people from other facilities, other departments, etc, to augment the staffing of experienced technicians on our project. We, the owner of the aircraft and his representatives understood this to be a commi

How do you explain this dismal effort by Gulfstream management to meet the demands of ours and other projects in this hangar, in this facility? There are many words that could be used to describe this situation - I won't use them but I will and can say with confidence that this is the greatest examp
